A 'bowl' is a common open-top container used in many cultures to serve food, and
is also used for drinking and storing other items. They are typically small and
shallow, although some, such as punch bowls and salad bowls, are larger and
often intended to serve many people.

Bowls have existed for thousands of years. Very early bowls have been found in
China, Ancient Greece, Crete and in certain Native American cultures. Modern bowls can be made of
ceramic, metal, wood, plastic, and other materials. Their appearance can range
from very simple designs of a single color to sophisticated artwork.

The bowl has also been used as a recepticle for the apple dunking game played
traditionally in Britain on Halloween. It is a game unique to the British Isles
and symbolises the traditional dunking of witches that was common for many
centuries as communities tried to find out who was a witch by dunking or
drowning them in the local river. It is said to originate in Queenstown Road,
Battersea although its ultimate origins may come from Highgate, London or the
East of the City.
